column4: Has anyone here actually gotten VLC to play Bluray discs in Ubuntu?
Yes, I did recently whilst testing a new BD drive. I tested it with the movie "Saving Private Ryan" which I assume was a copy-protected disc.
where did you put the Libaacs file? It doesn't go in the same place in Ubuntu as other Linux distros
I had to install the known keys to a directory in the user's home, but VLC looked there and used them
All the packages used were from the Ubuntu archives.
didn't you need to put in a file for the AACS dynamic library, too?
No, just the key files. I'm trying to find the document I used ... give me a mo, got to search back a month or more in browser history
Here it is! http://vlc-bluray.whoknowsmy.name/
actually, you just made me realize, I'll try doing that, too. On my VM which I tested it on, I tried using the file on the site, but didn't think to install the AACS packages.
yeah, using 12.04 libaacs was already installed
yeah, that's what I was going by. Installed the keys, but the site had the AACS stuff to install, too.
wait, what? Then it should've worked for me.
Yes, I'd assume so. Mine shows "apt-cache policy libaacs0 ... libaacs0:  Installed: 0.3.0-4"
And "ls -l ~/.config/aacs/  ...   -rw-rw-r-- 1 tj tj 3006 Apr 20  2012 KEYDB.cfg"

I've got Ubuntu 12.04 LTS, home/.comfig/aacs/KEYDB.cfg, and VLC that supports blu-ray playing, but if I try it tells me "Your system AACS decoding library does not work. Missing keys?" (testing with the movie Wall-E, which is fairly old)
Without a specific path they'll be in the directory where vlc starts from; usually $HOME I think
If the path you pasted in was correctly pasted - it's wrong. It should be "/home/$USER/.config/aacs/KEYDB.cfg" not "home/.comfig/aacs/KEYDB.cfg"
.comfig and lack of / in front of home were just errors on my part, not the actual path
OK. Have you started vlc from a terminal with verbose logging running? That may give a clue
where does VLC output its error logs in Ubuntu to?
to the launching terminal "vlc -v 10" or something similar, and you can capture to a log-file with "vlc -v 10 2>&1 | tee vlc.log"
well VLC has already made error logs, I just don't know where they are.
